item.title: Snowman Logistics Shares Soar 70% on Market Debut
item.description: Snowman Logistics - an integrated temperature controlled logistics service provider - got very good response for its IPO last month. The issue was oversubscribed nearly 60 times. Even the quota of ret...

item.title: On Camera, Villagers Beaten Mercilessly As 'Lesson' For Being Informers
item.description: A chilling video has emerged of villagers being beaten brutally in Meghalaya by suspected militants who allegedly wanted to make an example out of "informers".

item.title: Soldiers Asked to Remain Calm if Attacked with Stones, says Kashmir Army Commander
item.description: Soldiers working to rescue the thousands of people who still remain stranded in Srinagar have been asked to remain "very calm" if they are pelted with stones by angry crowds, a senior army officer tol...

item.title: What Was The Hurry to Close Birla Coal Case, Court Asks CBI
item.description: A Delhi court today asked the CBI to explain why it was in "in such a hurry" to close a case against top industrialist Kumar Mangalam Birla over the allotment of a coal block to his firm, Hindalco, in...

item.title: Opinion: PM Modi, Why Aren't You Reining in Adityanath?
item.description: Silence from the PM on hate speeches, writes Brinda Karat

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Found Guilty of Culpable Homicide
item.description: Celebrity athlete Oscar Pistorius was found guilty on Friday of culpable homicide in shooting dead his glamorous girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp, a conviction that could result in a lengthy jail term.

item.title: 'Love Jihad? What is That?' Asks Rajnath Singh
item.description: Home Minister Rajnath Singh today refused to answer a question on "love jihad" - a term that is currently in wide circulation among leaders of the BJP and its allied groups - and said "What is that?"

item.title: Ailing Italian Marine Allowed to go Home for 4 months by Supreme Court
item.description: The Supreme Court has allowed an Italian marine detained for the 2012 killing of two Kerala fishermen to fly home on medical grounds.

item.title: Movie Review: Finding Fanny
item.description: Watching Finding Fanny is like spending a night in a shack on a beach in Goa, drinking your poison and sharing mad jokes with friends all night

item.title: Haryana, Maharashtra Assembly Poll Dates Likely to be Announced Today
item.description: The Election Commission is likely to announce poll dates for Haryana and Maharashtra Assembly polls around 4:30 pm today.

item.title: Sharad Pawar Won't Share Stage With Rahul Gandhi. Still
item.description: The Congress' Maharashtra ally Sharad Pawar has refused to share the stage with Rahul Gandhi to campaign for state polls due next month.

item.title: India Topples China As World Leader in This Area
item.description: India will be the world's No. 1 cotton grower this year, ousting China from the top spot for the first time in over 30 years, the US government said on Thursday.

item.title: Accused of Misconduct, CBI Chief Offers Defense in Supreme Court
item.description: CBI chief Ranjit Sinha today supplied a written defense to the Supreme Court, in response to charges that he may have compromised investigations into some of the country's biggest financial scams by m...

item.title: SpiceJet Comes Up With Super Sale Offer Again
item.description: Budget carrier SpiceJet has announced a discount sale offer with fares starting from an all-inclusive Rs 1,999 for specific routes on its domestic network.

item.title: Ground Report: This Jammu Village Vanished from the Map
item.description: With the rain now stopping and interior areas of Jammu and Kashmir becoming accessible, the extent of damage in last week's devastating flood is becoming clearer.

item.title: Union Minister Sadananda Gowda's Son, Accused of Rape by Actress, Appears Before Police Finally
item.description: Union Minister Sadananda Gowda's son Karthik, who has been accused of rape and cheating by an actress, appeared before the police in Bangalore today in connection with the case against him.

item.title: Nithari Cannibal Surinder Koli's Execution Stayed Again by Supreme Court
item.description: Surinder Koli, the self-confessed cannibal found guilty of murdering a series of young women and children at a bungalow near Delhi, has asked the Supreme Court to review its decision that sentenced hi...

item.title: Steve Jobs Was a Low-Tech Parent
item.description: When Steve Jobs was running Apple, he was known to call journalists to either pat them on the back for a recent article or, more often than not, explain how they got it wrong.

item.title: Kashmir Floods: Educational Institutions Reopen in Jammu
item.description: With rain having stopped and water receding, educational institutions in the Jammu region, except those serving as relief camps for flood-affected people, reopened after almost a week today. In flood-...

item.title: Nokia Lumia 530 Dual SIM Review: Windows Phone 8.1 Made Affordable
item.description: Microsoft strengthens its position in the budget smartphone war with the Lumia 530 Dual SIM running Windows Phone 8.1.

item.title: Fodder Scam Convict Owes 44 Crores. His 18 Flats to be Auctioned Today
item.description: 18 flats belonging to one man - a convict in the multi-crore fodder scam of 1996 - will be auctioned in Bihar today by the Income Tax Department.

item.title: Shikaras to the Rescue on Kashmir's Flooded Paradise
item.description: Shikara owners, who normally ferry holidaymakers around the lake using only a wooden pole, have spent the last five days rescuing those stranded on sinking houseboats and bringing them to safety.

item.title: Double Solar Storms Headed to Earth Raise Disruption Concerns
item.description: A rare double burst of magnetically charged solar storms will hit Earth anytime after Thursday night, raising concerns that GPS signals, radio communications and power transmissions could be disrupted...

item.title: If Scotland Goes, Then Britain Too?
item.description: Tremors over a possible breakup of the United Kingdom have been felt here in recent days, as markets gyrate and banks make contingency plans.

item.title: India's Love Affair with Gold May be Over, as Prices Slide
item.description: The main beneficiary has been stocks, which have been clocking up records on hopes that Prime Minister Narendra Modi can deliver on the promise of "better days" ahead that swept him to power in May's ...
